formats.name: mini_poetry_reflection
formats.instruction: Express a feeling or observation as a 3-line poem. Each line should build or twist the meaning. Then add a one-sentence personal insight.

formats.name: reverse_wisdom
formats.instruction: Share a mistake or misconception you once held, then explain what finally made you change your mind. Use direct, impactful language.

formats.name: micro_manifesto
formats.instruction: Write a bold, one-sentence manifesto about something you care about, followed by a three-point bullet list of quick supporting arguments.

formats.name: imagined_future
formats.instruction: Describe a plausible 'day in the life' in a future 10-30 years from now, highlighting at least one surprising technological or social change.

formats.name: confession_chain
formats.instruction: Begin with a single 'I confess...' statement. Follow it with a sequence of 3-6 escalating admissions, each more unexpected than the last.

formats.name: audio_log_summary
formats.instruction: Pretend you’re recording an audio log for future generations after a major event. Chronicle what happened and your feelings in an urgent, report-like tone.

formats.name: data_driven_hyperfocus
formats.instruction: Pick an obscure statistic or fact. Provide three detailed paragraphs: context, implications, and a surprising personal connection. Include at least one reference.

formats.name: sensory_snapshot
formats.instruction: Vividly describe a single moment using at least three senses (sight, sound, touch, etc). End with a metaphor or analogy tying the moment to a bigger idea.

formats.name: question_map
formats.instruction: Pose one big question, then list four follow-up questions branching from it. For each, add a 1-sentence speculation or observation.

formats.name: recipe_remix
formats.instruction: Adapt a classic recipe to an unexpected new context (e.g., for astronauts, for the apocalypse). Describe the changes and why they’re needed in a playful tone.

title_styles: Write as a headline for a sci-fi magazine feature.
Make it a one-line haiku title (5-7-5 syllables).
Frame as a warning: 'Don’t ignore X or…'
Write as a mysterious teaser: 'If you know, you know.'
Start with a question and end with an exclamation mark.
structure_variants: Organize as a cascading waterfall of linked thoughts (each line connects to the next).
Use dialogue snippets between two contrasting characters.
Aim for a flashback/flashforward structure (jump through time).
Frame as a checklist with at least one misleading item.
topic_angles: Explore forgotten internet rituals from the early 2000s.
Analyze microhabits that change how people use public spaces.
Investigate 'junk drawer' psychology — why do we hoard odds and ends?
Examine how weather extremes reshape social interactions.
Deep dive into accidental inventions (products or ideas discovered by mistake).
